v.v: Do you know at what time the wild goats in the rocks bear their young?
Can you count the months that they gestate?
They crouch down and birth their young,
Their young ones become strong and grow up in the open fields;

v: Can you watch when the deer are having their fawns?
Do you know the time when they bear their young?
and then they finish their labor pains.
they go out and do not come back again.

v.v: Who let the wild donkey go free?
whose home I have made in the Arabah,
He laughs in scorn at the noises in the city;
He roams over the mountains as his pastures;
Will the wild ox be happy to serve you?
Can you use ropes to hold the wild ox in the furrows?
Will you trust him because his strength is great?
Will you depend on him to bring your grain home,

v: Who has untied the bonds of the swift donkey,
his house in the salt land?
he does not hear the driver’s shouts.
there he looks for every green plant to eat.
Will he consent to stay by your manger?
Will he harrow the valleys as he follows after you?
Will you leave your work to him to do?
to gather the grain for your threshing floor?

v.v: The wings of the ostrich wave proudly,
For she leaves her eggs on the earth,
she forgets that a foot might crush them
She deals roughly with her young ones as if they were not hers;
because God has deprived her of wisdom
When she runs swiftly,

v: but are they the pinions and plumage of love?
and she lets them keep warm in the dust;
or that a wild beast might trample them.
she does not fear that her labor might have been in vain,
and has not given her any understanding.
she laughs in scorn at the horse and its rider.

v.v: Have you given the horse his strength?
Have you ever made him jump like a locust?
He paws in might and rejoices in his strength;
He mocks fear and is not dismayed;
The quiver rattles against his flank,
He swallows up ground with fierceness and rage;
Whenever the trumpet sounds, he says, ‘Aha!’

v: Did you clothe his neck with his flowing mane?
The majesty of his snorting is fearsome.
he rushes out to meet the weapons.
he does not turn back from the sword.
along with the flashing spear and the javelin.
at the trumpet’s sound, he cannot stand in one place.
He smells the battle from far away—
the thunderous shouts of the commanders and the outcries.

v.v: Is it by your wisdom that the hawk soars,
Is it at your orders that the eagle mounts up
He lives on cliffs and makes his home
From there he searches for victims;
His young also drink up blood;

v: that he stretches out his wings for the south?
and makes his nest in high places?
on the peaks of cliffs, a stronghold.
his eyes see them from very far away.
where killed people are, there he is.”
